title: Mount Van der Hoeven
text: Mount Van der Hoeven () is a <a href="mountain">mountain</a> (1,940 m) at the north side of the head of <a href="Boggs%20Valley">Boggs Valley</a>, near the center of <a href="Helliwell%20Hills">Helliwell Hills</a>. It was mapped by <a href="United%20States%20Geological%20Survey">United States Geological Survey</a> (USGS) from surveys and <a href="U.S.%20Navy">U.S. Navy</a> air photos, 1960–63, and was named by the <a href="Advisory%20Committee%20on%20Antarctic%20Names">Advisory Committee on Antarctic Names</a> (US-ACAN) for <a href="Frans%20G.%20Van">Frans G. Van</a> der Hoeven, a seismologist and leader of the <a href="United%20States%20Antarctic%20Research%20Program">United States Antarctic Research Program</a> (USARP)-sponsored <a href="Victoria%20Land%20Traverse">Victoria Land Traverse</a>, 1959–60. The 1,530 mile seismic and topographic traverse in <a href="Tucker%20Sno-Cat">Tucker Sno-Cat</a> vehicles took a roughly triangular course, beginning at <a href="Hut%20Point%20Peninsula">Hut Point Peninsula</a>, <a href="Ross%20Island">Ross Island</a>, and ascending to the plateau of <a href="Victoria%20Land">Victoria Land</a> via <a href="Skelton%20Glacier">Skelton Glacier</a>. From there a northwest course was followed on interior plateau to . The party returned eastward, keeping south of the 72S parallel to (east side of <a href="Outback%20Nunataks">Outback Nunataks</a>), from where the party was evacuated by aircraft of U.S. Navy Squadron <a href="VX-6">VX-6</a>.
